They allegedly coordinated to release damaging information to sway the election under the names “DCLeaks” and “Guccifer 2.0.” However, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein told reporters that it’s unclear if their efforts changed the outcome of the election.
They are charged with hacking the computer networks of members of Hillary Clinton’s campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
In total, the indictment charges 11 spies with conspiracy to commit computer crimes, eight counts of aggravated identity theft, and conspiracy to launder money.
Special counsel Robert Mueller just indicted 12 Russian intelligence officers, accusing them of interfering in the 2016 US presidential election.
The indictment comes just days before President Donald Trump is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki.
Trump so far has said he believes Putin’s denials that his country interfered in the election in any way.
Two of the defendants are charged with a separate conspiracy to commit computer crimes.
According to Rosenstein, Trump knows about the indictment.
